docs.lead_paragraph: The death of a child often shortens the life of the mother, a Dutch study has found. The study, which was released last week by The Lancet, also found an increased risk of early death among fathers, but a far smaller one.
docs.abstract: Study finds that death of child often shortens life of mother, as well a life of father, to far smaller extent (S)
docs.snippet: The death of a child often shortens the life of the mother, a Dutch study has found.     The study, which was released last week by The Lancet, also found an increased risk of early death among fathers, but a far smaller one.

docs.lead_paragraph: All too many years ago, while I was still a psychology graduate student, I ran an experiment to assess how well meditation might work as an antidote to stress. My professors were skeptical, my measures were weak, and my subjects were mainly college sophomores. Not surprisingly, my results were inconclusive. But today I feel vindicated.

headline.main: Finding Happiness: Cajole Your Brain to Lean to the Left

docs.abstract: Daniel Goleman on practicing mindfulness to reduce stress and develop more positive outlook on life; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. As I ran my usual six miles in 15-degree weather, I was warned that it is dangerous to your lungs to exercise vigorously outdoors at frigid temperatures. Is this true? A. Even vigorous outdoor exercise in freezing air cannot freeze the lungs, said Dr. Ronald G. Crystal, chief of pulmonary and critical care medicine at New York-Presbyterian Hospital's Weill Cornell Center. But there is the risk of an asthma attack in some susceptible people, he said.
docs.abstract: Answer to reader's query about whether vigorous outdoor exercise in cold winter weather hurts lungs; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The first reaction from their best friends, users say, is almost always: ''Ewwww.'' Then, slowly, some come around. A few even become imbued with a missionary zeal to spread the word.

headline.main: Menstrual Cups, at Age 66, Begin to Make Up for Lost Time

docs.abstract: Use of menstrual cups--soft, flexible cups inserted to catch menses flow--is growing, especially at women's colleges and through alternative health Web sites; cups were first patented in America in 1930's, but never became popular; safety questions have been raised, but so far cups have not been linked to toxic shock syndrome or any other medical problem; poto (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Carol Guber's Type 2 Diabetes Life Plan,'' by Carol Guber, with Betsy Thorpe. Broadway Books, $25. Type 2 diabetes, also known as adult-onset diabetes, has become a highly common disorder, afflicting 16 million to 20 million people in the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: A woman who has been taking a prescription for her high blood pressure was advised by a friend to see an herbalist, who sold her a bag full of remedies. Now, the woman admits, she knows almost nothing about those remedies. Nor has she told her doctor about them. Are they safe? Are they pure? What drug effects do they have? And what side effects? Will they interact badly with her prescriptions and cause her blood pressure to plunge dangerously low?

headline.main: Herbal and Natural Don't Always Mean Safe

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on potential hazards of dietary supplements and herbal remedies; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Even among people who do not have diabetes, poor glucose tolerance appears to be linked to weaker memory, according to a study released yesterday. The finding suggests that people may be able to reduce their risk of memory decline -- and perhaps even reverse any decline that has occurred -- through diet and exercise, said the lead author of the study, Dr. Antonio J. Convit of the Nathan Kline Research Institute at the New York University School of Medicine.

headline.main: Jog Your Memory? At the Gym?

docs.abstract: Study finds that even among people who do not have diabetes, poor glucose tolerance appears to be linked to weaker memory; finding suggests that people may be able to reduce their risk of memory decline through diet and exercise (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 jail inmates in Los Angeles County have suffered painful and aggressive skin infections caused by a bacterium resistant to many antibiotics, medical authorities say. The unusual outbreak over the last year is still not contained. The same pathogen, which causes fast-growing boils and unsightly abscesses, also appears to have infected dozens of gay men, many of them H.I.V. patients, in Los Angeles and San Francisco, health officials say.

headline.main: Mystery Surrounds a Virulent Skin Infection

docs.abstract: Medical authorities say that more than 1,000 jail inmates in Los Angeles County have suffered painful and aggressive skin infection caused by bacterium resistant to many antibiotics; unsual outbreak over last year is still not contained; health officials say that same pathogen, which causes fast-growing boils and unsightly abscesses, also appears to have infected dozens of gay men, many of them HIV patients, in Los Angeles and San Francisco; experts are worried because this strain of bacterium is spreading outside its traditional setting; photo of Dr Elizabeth Bancroft (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I didn't want to work in the intensive care unit. Maybe it'll be different this year, my wife said. After all, I was no longer an intern. Maybe, I replied. I didn't tell anyone the reason for my reluctance: I didn't want to carry the code beeper. Through residency I dreaded the day I would have to be a code leader -- the one who resuscitates patients, the fearless leader barking orders, making snap judgments, saving lives.

headline.main: Trial by Fire, And by Fear, In the I.C.U.

docs.abstract: Dr Sandeep Jauhar column on his trial-by-fire experience working as code leader in intensive care unit, doctor who is responsible for resuscitating patients, barking out orders, making snap judgments, to try to save lives (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Studies of medical errors generally focus on those in hospitals. But a new study suggests that injuries stemming from mistakes made when patients are discharged from hospitals or in their follow-up care may be more common, though not as serious. For the study, which was released yesterday by The Annals of Internal Medicine, researchers from Harvard and the University of Ottawa interviewed 400 randomly chosen patients three weeks after they left hospitals and examined their records.
docs.abstract: Study suggests that injuries stemming from medical mistakes made when patients are discharged from hospitals or in their follow-up care may be more common, thought not as serious, as those made in hospitals (S)
docs.snippet: Studies of medical errors generally focus on those in hospitals. But a new study suggests that injuries stemming from mistakes made when patients are discharged from hospitals or in their follow-up care may be more common, though not as serious.   ...
